pullRequest.title: add OAuth authority
pullRequest.bodyText:
TODO

add auth0 dependency to the release version of this PR

changes

related files:

update jjwt.version

fix pom.xml: 3f05aa5

related files:

libs/java/auth_core/*




fix existing test cases: 70d39b4

fix io.jsonwebtoken.security.WeakKeyException after version update

clients/java/zpe/*
servers/zts/*






support Auth0 as Athenz IdP: 34c8089
minor fixes

fix dead link: c5dc330
remove bouncer: 70ae183
fix whitespace: 897e503

nodes.bodyText: String values are compared using ==, not equals()
this is quite an old version of athenz. let's use the latest release.

nodes.bodyText: where/how are we using this example.com/client_id? do we need a such value as default or is the caller expected to always specify a value?

I would suggest if we have a AthenzUtils.getPrincipal method then that method should already return values in lowercase since that's what Athenz uses everywhere. Then we don't have to remember to call toLowerCase() everywhere.
we should keep the number of dependencies in auth_core minimal so not sure why we're using this but it doesn't look right.
seems inconsistent that we lowercase service but not domain?
we have :role. defined in AuthortyConsts so we should use that here

why did we create this class? we already have the SigningKeyResolver without relying on auth0 implementation and it supports both rsa and ec keys. So rather than creating yet another and adding dependency on auth0 library, take a look at the current key resolver and if necessary extend that class.
we should probably log these errors otherwise it's very difficult to debug any issues.
lets include a log error entry for this as well.
seems to be inefficient to handle just a single string. we can just create a set and add the entry without creating additional objects.
I'd suggesting adding a comment explaining that otherwise it does look suspicious
I think I made a comment earlier about this. it looks like this method already does the to lowercase conversion thus the caller doesn't need to call it again.
